012package org.postgresql.pljava.example.annotation;
013
014import java.sql.ResultSet;
015import java.sql.ResultSetMetaData;
016import java.sql.SQLException;
017
018import static java.util.Arrays.fill;
019
020import org.postgresql.pljava.ResultSetProvider;
021import org.postgresql.pljava.annotation.Function;
022import org.postgresql.pljava.annotation.SQLAction;
023import org.postgresql.pljava.annotation.SQLType;
024
025/**
026 * Example demonstrating the use of a {@code RECORD} parameter as a way to
027 * supply an arbitrary sequence of named, typed parameters to a PL/Java
028 * function.
029 *<p>
030 * Also tests the proper DDR generation of defaults for such parameters.
031 *<p>
032 * This example relies on {@code implementor} tags reflecting the PostgreSQL
033 * version, set up in the {@link ConditionalDDR} example.
034 */
035@SQLAction(
036    provides = "paramtypeinfo type", // created in Triggers.java
037    install = {
038        "CREATE TYPE javatest.paramtypeinfo AS (" +
039        " name text, pgtypename text, javaclass text, tostring text" +
040        ")"
041    },
042    remove = {
043        "DROP TYPE javatest.paramtypeinfo"
044    }
045)
046public class RecordParameterDefaults implements ResultSetProvider
047{
048    /**
049     * Return the names, types, and values of parameters supplied as a single
050     * anonymous RECORD type; the parameter is given an empty-record default,
051     * allowing it to be omitted in calls, or used with the named-parameter
052     * call syntax.
053     *<p>
054     * For example, this function could be called as:
055     *<pre>
056     * SELECT (paramDefaultsRecord()).*;
057     *</pre>
058     * or as:
059     *<pre>
060     * SELECT (paramDefaultsRecord(params =&gt; s)).*
061     * FROM (SELECT 42 AS a, '42' AS b, 42.0 AS c) AS s;
062     *</pre>
063     */
064    @Function(
065        requires = "paramtypeinfo type",
066        schema = "javatest",
067        implementor = "postgresql_ge_80400", // supports function param DEFAULTs
068        type = "javatest.paramtypeinfo"
069        )
070    public static ResultSetProvider paramDefaultsRecord(
071        @SQLType(defaultValue={})ResultSet params)
072    throws SQLException
073    {
074        return new RecordParameterDefaults(params);
075    }
076
077    /**
078     * Like paramDefaultsRecord but illustrating the use of a named row type
079     * with known structure, and supplying a default for the function
080     * parameter.
081     *<p>
082     *<pre>
083     * SELECT paramDefaultsNamedRow();
084     *
085     * SELECT paramDefaultsNamedRow(userWithNum =&gt; ('fred', 3.14));
086     *</pre>
087     */
088    @Function(
089        requires = "foobar tables", // created in Triggers.java
090        implementor = "postgresql_ge_80400", // supports function param DEFAULTs
091        schema = "javatest"
092        )
093    public static String paramDefaultsNamedRow(
094        @SQLType(value="javatest.foobar_2", defaultValue={"bob", "42"})
095        ResultSet userWithNum)
096    throws SQLException
097    {
098        return String.format("username is %s and value is %s",
099            userWithNum.getObject("username"), userWithNum.getObject("value"));
100    }
101
102
103
104    private final ResultSetMetaData m_paramrsmd;
105    private final Object[] m_values;
106    
107    RecordParameterDefaults(ResultSet paramrs) throws SQLException
108    {
109        m_paramrsmd = paramrs.getMetaData();
110        /*
111         * Grab the values from the parameter SingleRowResultSet now; it isn't
112         * guaranteed to stay valid for the life of the set-returning function.
113         */
114        m_values = new Object [ m_paramrsmd.getColumnCount() ];
115        for ( int i = 0; i < m_values.length; ++ i )
116            m_values[i] = paramrs.getObject( 1 + i);
117    }
118
119    @Override
120    public boolean assignRowValues(ResultSet receiver, int currentRow)
121    throws SQLException
122    {
123        int col = 1 + currentRow;
124        if ( col > m_paramrsmd.getColumnCount() )
125            return false;
126        receiver.updateString("name", m_paramrsmd.getColumnLabel(col));
127        receiver.updateString("pgtypename", m_paramrsmd.getColumnTypeName(col));
128        Object o = m_values[col - 1];
129        receiver.updateString("javaclass", o.getClass().getName());
130        receiver.updateString("tostring", o.toString());
131        return true;
132    }
133
134    @Override
135    public void close() throws SQLException
136    {
137        fill(m_values, null);
138    }
139}
